resources.text: Java has undergone many changes since its release. Take a look at this version table from Wikipedia:
Here is what may change in a new release:

Deprecating a method or a class means marking it for removal in a future version. In most cases, a suitable replacement is given. Deprecated code can still be used, however, it's recommended to use the replacement instead.
resources.boxed: Deprecated code is marked with the @Deprecated annotation. Your compiler will raise a warning if you use such a method or class.
resources.text: For example much of the class java.util.Date has been deprecated, because a better alternative has been added in Java 7, called the java.time package.
In each version, new classes, methods and sometimes even entire packages are added to the standard library. These could be:
resources.list:
• Better implementations of previously present code (in this case, the previous code is ofter deprecated).
  • Code that brings some entirely new functionality.
resources.text: For example, in Java 7, the package java.nio package was added (the name stands for New IO).
resources.code:
try {
    List<String> lines = Files.readAllLines(Paths.get("myfile.txt"));
} catch(IOException e) {
    System.err.println("Failed to read from file!");
}
resources.text: Before the NIO package, programmers had to use readers and loops to achieve this.
These are the most significant changes. New keywords and structures may be introduced, and the syntax of Java can change, allowing the programmer to be more productive.
resources.boxed: For instance, Java 5 introduced generics, which was a significant extension to Java.
resources.text: This course is about Java 8. However, if you take a look at the version table again, you'll notice that it is not at all the latest release. So, what makes it so significant that it deserves its own course?
resources.boxed: Java 8 became the most widely used version, despite the newer releases. This is partly because it offered so many new things, and partly because the newer version did not, so many programmers and companies simply did not consider worth their time to upgrade.
resources.text: In the following chapters, we'll take a look at the most important changes of Java 8, with detailed explanations and examples!
